nodes.text: The common use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) causes artifactual results — notably a monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon price — that misrepresent long-term technological energy transitions
IAMs are widely used to link economic output, greenhouse gas emissions, climate change, and policy levers producing carbon price trajectories used for policy guidance

CES functions were developed for capital-labor substitution and are share-preserving: marginal rate of technical substitution depends on factor ratios and for a large incumbent share they mathematically require exponentially increasing input of substitutes to maintain output

Applying CES to technical energy inputs over long periods where one factor may be fully substituted is inappropriate because technical substitution elasticities evolve and transitions follow S-curve diffusion, not constant elasticity
IAM structure typically: represent decades-long economy, translate activity to GHG emissions, estimate temperature change, and convert temperature impacts to GDP damages to derive carbon prices

Mathematical derivation and example show CES implies: exponentially increasing renewable input required to replace fossil fuels, substitution saturates well before full replacement, carbon price to force substitution rises exponentially, and results are sensitive to chosen elasticity
Many prominent IAMs (examples: DICE variants, GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, MARKAL/MEANS hybrids) use nested CES or CES variants in economic and energy production modules

Historical technological and energy transitions empirically follow S-curve or logistic-like diffusion with accelerating adoption, learning, and falling costs, implying dynamically changing elasticity of substitution
Because CES is share-preserving and assumes constant elasticity, it cannot reproduce the empirical accelerating substitution and cost-decline behavior observed in historical energy transitions

Stylized CES example in the paper: with global fossil share 85% reducing to 55% can require a 13-fold increase in renewables for some elasticity values and carbon taxes reaching orders of magnitude above unit fossil costs

Model outputs from GTEM-C, EPPA, GCAM, MERGE and others exhibit the CES-driven artifact: carbon prices rise steeply late century (hundreds to thousands USD per tCO2) and energy mixes remain fossil-heavy or dominated by technologies pre-specified in the model

Empirical studies and literature (logistic, Gompertz, Bass diffusion, historical energy data) document consistent patterns of exponential deployment and cost reduction during diffusion across sectors and energy technologies

Policy-relevant consequences of the CES-induced artifacts include: price diversion (overreliance on setting carbon prices instead of physical deployment planning), sticker shock (perception that mitigation costs are politically impossible), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent included technologies like CCS, nuclear, biomass rather than emerging options)

Model comparison studies that fix carbon price or impose shocks still show rapid, often physically implausible, changes in technology deployment (e.g., massive nuclear or biomass with CCS growth in short periods), consistent with CES-driven constraints rather than engineering feasibility

A practical modification is to use dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to expected technical profiles, which can reproduce S-curve transition dynamics and avoid exponential carbon price artifacts within existing modeling frameworks

Fundamental recommendation: preference for modeling approaches grounded in physical energy principles and deployment targets (including dynamic elasticity or physics-driven models) to produce policy-relevant, realistic projections of energy transitions and carbon prices
